sen.j: 瀧 廉太郎（たき れんたろう、1879年8月24日 - 1903年6月29日）は、日本の音楽家・作曲家。
sen.e: Rentaro TAKI (August 24, 1879 - June 29, 1903) was a Japanese musician and composer.
Rentaro TAKI (August 24, 1879 - June 29, 1903) was a Japanese musician and composer.
Rentaro TAKI (August 24, 1879 - June 29, 1903) was a Japanese musician and composer.

sen.j: 明治の西洋音楽黎明期における代表的な音楽家の一人である。
sen.e: He was one of leading musicians who lived at the early stage of the development of Western music in Japan in the Meiji period.
He lived during the early stages of the development of Western music in Japan in the Meiji era, and was one of the leading musicians of the period.
He lived during the early stages of the development of Western music in Japan in the Meiji era, and was one of the leading musicians of the period.

sen.j: 1879年（明治12年）東京生まれ。
sen.e: He was born in Tokyo in 1879.
He was born in Tokyo in 1879.
He was born in Tokyo in 1879.

sen.j: 瀧家は江戸時代、日出藩（現・大分県日出町）の家老職をつとめた上級武士の家柄である。
sen.e: The Taki family was from such a high-ranking warrior class that they served as a karo (chief retainer) at the Hiji Domain (present-day Hiji-machi, Oita Prefecture) during the Edo period.
The Taki family was from the warrior class, and of such a high rank that they had served as a karo (chief retainer) in Hiji Domain (present-day Hiji-machi, Oita Prefecture) during the Edo period.
The Taki family was from the warrior class, and of such a high rank that they had served as a karo (chief retainer) in Hiji Domain (present-day Hiji-machi, Oita Prefecture) during the Edo period.

sen.j: 父・吉弘は大蔵省に勤務後内務省 (日本)に転じ大久保利通､伊藤博文らのもとで中央の官吏として務めた。
sen.e: His father Yoshihiro was transferred to the Ministry of Interior after the Ministry of Finance, and he worked as an official of the central government under the supervision of Toshimichi OKUBO and Hirofumi ITO.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処原文に「内務省 (日本)」とありますがリンク先の用語と混ざっているようです。ウェブを確認し「内務省」として訳出いたしました。
sen.e: His father Yoshihiro was transferred to the Ministry of Interior from the Ministry of Finance, and worked as a central government official under the supervision of Toshimichi OKUBO and Hirofumi ITO.
His father Yoshihiro was transferred to the Ministry of Interior from the Ministry of Finance, and worked as a central government official under the supervision of Toshimichi OKUBO and Hirofumi ITO.

sen.j: その後地方官として神奈川県､富山県富山市、大分県竹田市等を移り住んだため、瀧も生後間もなくから各地を回ることとなった。
sen.e: After that, he lived in several places such as Kanagawa Prefecture, Toyama City in Toyama Prefecture, and Taketa City in Oita Prefecture as he worked as a local official, and accordingly, Taki also had to go from place to place soon after his birth.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: He subsequently worked as a local official, which involved moves to several places, among them Kanagawa Prefecture, Toyama City in Toyama Prefecture, and Taketa City in Oita Prefecture; accordingly, soon after his birth, Taki also had to go from place to place.

He subsequently worked as a local official, which involved moves to several places, among them Kanagawa Prefecture, Toyama City in Toyama Prefecture, and Taketa City in Oita Prefecture; accordingly, soon after his birth, Taki also had to go from place to place.

sen.j: 1894年（明治27年）に15歳で東京音楽学校（現・東京芸術大学）に入学する。
sen.e: He entered Tokyo Music School (present-day Tokyo University of the Arts) in 1894 at the age of 15.
Taki entered Tokyo Music School (present-day Tokyo University of the Arts) in 1894 at the age of 15.
Taki entered Tokyo Music School (present-day Tokyo University of the Arts) in 1894 at the age of 15.

sen.j: 1898年に本科を卒業し、研究科に進む。
sen.e: He finished the regular course in 1898, and then he went to the graduate school.
He finished the regular courses in 1898, then went to the graduate school.
He finished the regular courses in 1898, then went to the graduate school.

sen.j: こうして彼は作曲とピアノ演奏でめきめきと才能を伸ばしていった。
sen.e: He developed his talents for music composition and piano performance with remarkable speed.
He developed his talents for music composition and piano performance with remarkable speed.
He developed his talents for music composition and piano performance with remarkable speed.

sen.j: 1900年10月7日には、東京にあった聖公会博愛教会で洗礼を受けてキリスト教徒になった。
sen.e: On October 7, 1900, he was baptized into the Christian faith at the Grace Episcopal Church, which belonged to the Anglican-Episcopal Church, in Tokyo.
On October 7, 1900, he was baptized into the Christian faith at Grace Episcopal Church, which was affiliated with the Anglican-Episcopal Church, in Tokyo.
On October 7, 1900, he was baptized into the Christian faith at Grace Episcopal Church, which was affiliated with the Anglican-Episcopal Church, in Tokyo.

sen.j: 10月28日に堅信礼を受けた。
sen.e: He had confirmation on October 28.
He was confirmed on October 28.
He was confirmed on October 28.

sen.j: 明治時代の前半に多くの翻訳唱歌ができたが、日本語訳詞を"無理にはめこんだ"ぎこちない歌が多く、日本人作曲家によるオリジナルの歌を望む声が高まっていた。
sen.e: Although many foreign songs were translated for school music classes in the early Meiji period, most of them were awkward as translated lyrics were forcibly set to the music, and accordingly, there was high demand for Japanese songs composed by Japanese composers.

Although many foreign songs were translated for school music classes in the early Meiji period, most of them were awkward, with translated lyrics forcibly set to the music; accordingly, there was high demand for Japanese songs composed by Japanese composers.

Although many foreign songs were translated for school music classes in the early Meiji period, most of them were awkward, with translated lyrics forcibly set to the music; accordingly, there was high demand for Japanese songs composed by Japanese composers.

sen.j: 瀧は最も早く、その要望に応えた作曲家と言えるだろう。
sen.e: Taki can be said to have been the first composer who responded to that demand.
Taki can be said to have been the first composer to respond to that demand.
Taki can be said to have been the first composer to respond to that demand.

sen.j: 彼の代表作である「荒城の月」は、「箱根八里」と並んで文部省編纂の「中学唱歌」に掲載された。
sen.e: One of his most important pieces 'Kojo no Tsuki' (The Moon over the Deserted Castle) was adopted into the music book for junior high schools, which was compiled by the Ministry of Education, along with his another song called 'Hakone Hachiri.'
sen.cmt: 「箱根八里」について、ここでは用語集の「Traditional local folk song in the Hakone district」という説明はふさわしくないため（地方の歌ではなく、瀧廉太郎による作曲ということが明らかなため）省略しました。
sen.e: Kojo no Tsuki' (The Moon over the Deserted Castle), one of his most important pieces, was adopted into the music book compiled by the Ministry of Education for junior high schools, along with another of his songs, 'Hakone Hachiri.'

Kojo no Tsuki' (The Moon over the Deserted Castle), one of his most important pieces, was adopted into the music book compiled by the Ministry of Education for junior high schools, along with another of his songs, 'Hakone Hachiri.'

sen.j: また、人気の高い曲のひとつである「花 (滝廉太郎)」は1900年（明治33年）8月に作曲された、4曲からなる組曲『四季』の第1曲である。
sen.e: One of his popular songs 'Hana' (Flowers) is the first song of his suite "Shiki" (Four Seasons) consisting of four songs, which was composed in August 1900.
sen.cmt: 原文に「花 (滝廉太郎)」とありますがリンク先の用語と混ざっているようです。ウェブを確認し「花」として訳出いたしました。
sen.e: Hana' (Flowers), one of his popular songs, is the first song of his suite "Shiki" (Four Seasons), which consists of four songs and was composed in August 1900.
Hana' (Flowers), one of his popular songs, is the first song of his suite "Shiki" (Four Seasons), which consists of four songs and was composed in August 1900.

sen.j: 「お正月」、「鳩ぽっぽ」、「雪やこんこ」などは、日本生まれの最も古い童謡作品として知られるが、これらは1900年に編纂された幼稚園唱歌に収められた名曲である。
sen.e: His songs such as 'Oshogatsu' (New Year's Day), 'Hato Poppo' (Pigeons), and 'Yuki Ya Konko' (Japanese Snow Song) are known as the oldest nursery songs which were composed in Japan, and these songs are such excellent pieces that were included in the music book for kindergarten students compiled in 1900.

His songs 'Oshogatsu' (New Year's Day), 'Hato Poppo' (Pigeons), and 'Yuki Ya Konko' (Japanese Snow Song) are known as the oldest nursery songs to be composed in Japan, and are such excellent pieces that they were included in the music book compiled in 1900 for kindergarten students.

His songs 'Oshogatsu' (New Year's Day), 'Hato Poppo' (Pigeons), and 'Yuki Ya Konko' (Japanese Snow Song) are known as the oldest nursery songs to be composed in Japan, and are such excellent pieces that they were included in the music book compiled in 1900 for kindergarten students.

sen.j: また「荒城の月」は、ベルギーで讃美歌になったことも判明した。
sen.e: In addition, it has become known that some Belgians sang 'Kojo no Tsuki' as a hymn.
In addition, it has become known that 'Kojo no Tsuki' was converted into a hymn in Belgium.
In addition, it has become known that 'Kojo no Tsuki' was converted into a hymn in Belgium.

sen.j: 1901年（明治34年）4月、日本人の音楽家として2人目にヨーロッパ（ドイツ）のフェリックス・メンデルスゾーン音楽演劇大学（フェリックス・メンデルスゾーン設立）に留学する。
sen.e: He entered the University of Music and Theatre "Felix Mendelssohn Bartholdy" Leipzig (established by Felix Mendelssohn) in Europe (Germany) in April 1901, and he was the second Japanese composer who entered this school.

In April 1901, Taki entered the European University of Music and Theatre "Felix Mendelssohn Bartholdy" Leipzig (established by Felix Mendelssohn) in Germany, becoming the second Japanese composer to attend this school.

In April 1901, Taki entered the European University of Music and Theatre "Felix Mendelssohn Bartholdy" Leipzig (established by Felix Mendelssohn) in Germany, becoming the second Japanese composer to attend this school.

sen.j: 文部省外国留学生として入学、ピアノや対位法などを学ぶが、わずか2ヶ月後に肺結核を発病し、1年で帰国を余儀なくされる。
sen.e: He was sent abroad to this school by the Ministry of Education and he took piano lessons and learned counterpoint, but only two months later, he caught tuberculosis and had to return to Japan one year after he entered the school.

He entered the school as a Ministry of Education exchange student; he took piano lessons and learned counterpoint, but after only two months, he caught tuberculosis and had to return to Japan one year after entering the school.

He entered the school as a Ministry of Education exchange student; he took piano lessons and learned counterpoint, but after only two months, he caught tuberculosis and had to return to Japan one year after entering the school.

sen.j: その後父親の故郷である大分県で療養していたが、1903年（明治36年）6月29日に23歳の若さで死去した。
sen.e: He received medical treatment in Oita Prefecture, which was his father's hometown, but he died on June 29, 1903 at the premature age of 23.
He received medical treatment in Oita Prefecture, his father's home prefecture, but on June 29, 1903, he died at the young age of 23.
He received medical treatment in Oita Prefecture, his father's home prefecture, but on June 29, 1903, he died at the young age of 23.

sen.j: 墓所は大分市の熊野寺にある。
sen.e: His graveyard is at Kumano-ji (熊野寺) Temple in Oita City.
sen.cmt: 熊野寺の正式な読み方が不明です
sen.e: His grave is at Kumano-ji (熊野寺) Temple in Oita City.
His grave is at Kumano-ji (熊野寺) Temple in Oita City.

sen.j: 歌曲に有名な作品が多い瀧だが、1900年には日本人作曲家による初めてのピアノ独奏曲メヌエット (滝廉太郎)を作曲している。
sen.e: Although Taki made many popular songs, he also composed a piano solo called Minuet in 1900, and this was the first piano solo made by a Japanese composer.
sen.cmt: 原文に「メヌエット (滝廉太郎)」とありますがリンク先の用語と混ざっているようです。ウェブを確認し「メヌエット」として訳出いたしました。
sen.e: Although Taki wrote many popular songs, he also composed a piano solo called Minuet in 1900, which became the first piano solo by a Japanese composer.
Although Taki wrote many popular songs, he also composed a piano solo called Minuet in 1900, which became the first piano solo by a Japanese composer.

sen.j: 肺結核が悪化して、死期が近いことを悟った時、死の4ヶ月前に作曲したピアノ曲「憾 (滝廉太郎)（うらみ）」が最後の作品として残された。
sen.e: As he realized he would die soon due to the worsening of his pulmonary tuberculosis, he composed a piece of music for the piano named 'Urami' (regret) four months before his death, and this became his last work.
sen.cmt: 原文に「憾 (滝廉太郎)」とありますがリンク先の用語と混ざっているようです。ウェブを確認し「憾」として訳出いたしました。
sen.e: His pulmonary tuberculosis worsened, and when he realized he would soon die, he composed a piano piece titled 'Urami' (Regret) four months before his death; this became his last work.
His pulmonary tuberculosis worsened, and when he realized he would soon die, he composed a piano piece titled 'Urami' (Regret) four months before his death; this became his last work.

sen.j: また、後に、「箱根八里」は、箱根登山鉄道の発車メロディーになる。
sen.e: Also, his song 'Hakone Hachri' became a departure song of trains of Hakone Tozan Railway afterward.
His song 'Hakone Hachiri' later became the departure song for Hakone Tozan Railway trains.
His song 'Hakone Hachiri' later became the departure song for Hakone Tozan Railway trains.

sen.j: 「花」は、東北新幹線・上越新幹線の上野駅到着・発車時の車内チャイム（通称「ふるさとチャイム」）として使われていたが、東京駅開業後は使用されていない。
sen.e: His song 'Hana' used to be used as an alarm within a train (generally known as Furusato Chime [literally, "Hometown Chime"]) for a departure and an arrival at Ueno Station for Tohoku Shinkansen and Joetsu Shinkansen, but they stopped using that song when Tokyo Station opened.

His song 'Hana' was formerly used as an onboard alert (generally known as the Furusato Chime [literally, "Hometown Chime"]) for Tohoku and Joetsu Shinkansen departures and arrivals at Ueno Station, but they stopped using the song after the opening of Tokyo Station.

His song 'Hana' was formerly used as an onboard alert (generally known as the Furusato Chime [literally, "Hometown Chime"]) for Tohoku and Joetsu Shinkansen departures and arrivals at Ueno Station, but they stopped using the song after the opening of Tokyo Station.

sen.j: メヌエット・「憾」を除いて、全て声楽作品である。
sen.e: All his works are songs except for Minuet and Urami.
All his works are written to be sung, except for Minuet and Urami.
All his works are written to be sung, except for Minuet and Urami.

sen.j: 日本男児 （詞・東郊。独唱）
sen.e: Nippon Danji (literally, "a son of Japan," lyrics by Ko TO [東郊], a solo piece)
sen.cmt: 東郊の正式な読みが不明です
sen.e: Nippon Danji (literally "A Son of Japan," a solo piece with lyrics by Ko TO [東郊])
Nippon Danji (literally "A Son of Japan," a solo piece with lyrics by Ko TO [東郊])
